verses.name: Proverbs 27:1
verses.text: Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:2
verses.text: Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:3
verses.text: A stone is heavy, and the sand weighty; but a fool’s wrath is heavier than them both.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:4
verses.text: Wrath is cruel, and anger is outrageous; but who is able to stand before envy?

verses.name: Proverbs 27:5
verses.text: Open rebuke is better than secret love.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:6
verses.text: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:7
verses.text: The full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:8
verses.text: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that wandereth from his place.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:9
verses.text: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so doth the sweetness of a man’s friend by hearty counsel.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:10
verses.text: Thine own friend, and thy father’s friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity: for better is a neighbour that is near than a brother far off.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:11
verses.text: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:12
verses.text: A prudent man foreseeth the evil, and hideth himself; but the simple pass on, and are punished.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:13
verses.text: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:14
verses.text: He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:15
verses.text: A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:16
verses.text: Whosoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand, which bewrayeth itself.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:17
verses.text: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:18
verses.text: Whoso keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:19
verses.text: As in water face answereth to face, so the heart of man to man.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:20
verses.text: Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:21
verses.text: As the fining pot for silver, and the furnace for gold; so is a man to his praise.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:22
verses.text: Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, yet will not his foolishness depart from him.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:23
verses.text: Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks, and look well to thy herds.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:24
verses.text: For riches are not for ever: and doth the crown endure to every generation?

verses.name: Proverbs 27:25
verses.text: The hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:26
verses.text: The lambs are for thy clothing, and the goats are the price of the field.

verses.name: Proverbs 27:27
verses.text: And thou shalt have goats’ milk enough for thy food, for the food of thy household, and for the maintenance for thy maidens.
